@joonian But institutions can buy/sell from lots of sources, at whatever price they think is reasonable (based on their data & expectations). Information syncs “reasonable” way faster than it used to, but breakers allow time to gather more data so you don’t buy irrationally spooked quotes

@joonian There’s a LOT going on *waves hands* but a “ticker price” is the mid of what various market makers (ppl & machines) announce they are willing to buy and sell [some quantity] at. Your retail broker is obligated to trade their inventory near a quote from a pre-agreed pricing source

@joonian The vast majority of trades don’t happen at the prices you see on the screen or from inventory that’s anywhere near an exchange. When a breaker trips, it gives the tangled web of connected systems time to sort things out, so there’s a more accurate pic of the world on resume

@ChrisBlec The dedicated industry-only radio lines are antifragile, but still expensive per-participant to build a tribal social good. The centralized phone tree protected staff, but it only existed in so much as your living/producing matters to The Company. \n\nJust thinking out loud.

@ChrisBlec Antifragility is great for people that don’t/won’t take orders from each other, but also depends on lots of participants knowing & caring (eg buying a radio or knowing how to broadcast). Centralization is great for organizing a hierarchical group where the goal is protect the top

@ChrisBlec I was just starting out in my career then at a trading firm in FL & was blown away to learn about all the separate dedicated infrastructure that connects financial firms and exchanges, separate govt run phone lines “select staff” can access with PINs, etc. They never lost contact

@TheHonorableAT The phone tree stuff was amazing and not something I would have thought of otherwise without training. I never wanted to give my # out to my whole team (thx creepy dude) but my mgr could still verify my safety. Great stuff.

Oh, and on that walk I saw a bunch of NYU kids trying to buy food at their downstairs bodega, absolutely outraged that the shopkeeper refused to take their credit cards. The city was dark! Always have some cash, my friends. 😂\n\n(Yes, this also applies to your mobile coin wallet)

I remember walking on foot from SoHo to the midtown JPMorgan HQ when power was out all over the city after Sandy, because they had generators, Internet, and ironclad DR plans. Centralization has its benefits.

We’re not currently at risk of major infrastructure disruption in the US, but having seen how difficult it is to keep systems running & teams safe after multiple hurricane shut downs in FL & NY, this is a great time to think about your holistic plan

It’s nice to be part of the “we’re already remote-first” smug train, but remember resilience is also: 
- Where’s my next source of Internet if mine is interrupted?
- What are my team’s phone numbers & how do we regularly check in?
- How do we do support with a skeleton staff? Etc

@gdemchak17 The Iowa caucus was an open ballot, which (combined with the paper trail) is why the issue is reporting logistics and not vote inaccuracy.\n\nNo publicly audited system has successfully combined verifiably-one-human digital IDs, secret ballots, and a public ledger.

At the risk of over-explaining... design is more than just technical choices and avoiding possible bugs & backdoors. It's how you package, test, deploy, educate, measure progress, etc. If your fear of failure overrides your ability to evaluate risk clearly, we lose.

Thread\nAnd while it's *super good* that in this instance, the votes were backed on paper, that seems like the only silver lining. Closed source systems built by for-profit companies are not properly incentivized to make the right design choices for public voting systems.

This Iowa caucus debacle should be a launchpad for serious mainstream discussion about the complexity and perils of electronic voting, but let's be real - we're just going to scapegoat the app makers and do it again. https://t.co/IhWdZOtxHD

I don’t mean to get so serious on the bird site, but people keep asking me my “path to a successful career” and it’s a mix of rage fueled banging on closed doors and not dying. And I have rarely ever worked outside 9-6. <fin>

I’ve done work as a mental crisis counselor because of the ills that plague “successful & smart” tech people — and please let me tell you, it doesn’t matter what your 20s or your yesterday looked like, what matters is that you find a reason to want to be a success: hope

I get it, find a passion project and live your best life. But that is a *narrow* scope of experience and definition of success, and besides discounting people who “succeed” on other paths, it lies about the way you should look & feel to know you’re “on your way.” Don’t buy it. https://t.co/7he4LceSWO

TL;DR: I was made to feel like I was doing something wrong by exercising my right to refuse electronic search, and told that right will disappear in the next year. Everyone was professional about it. After all, it's just procedure. <fin>

We chat for a while (it takes a WHILE...they fully unpack and scan everything) about why it's important people who "look like me" are proactive about privacy and security. He says he likes my style. I might have gotten through to bag guy. But I also have one more file somewhere.

The bag search guy just does his job, he was really nice and kind of apologetic. He asks why I'd put myself through this; it seems like I might be the only person he's ever searched voluntarily. I ask him if he thinks privacy is a human right, he says he's never thought about it.

The search was standard but 2x as long. They've set the metal detector so sensitively that it goes off literally everywhere. (Sadly, I am not made of metal. That would be cool tho) They lecture me on how the machines aren't connected to the internet, then tell me I'm free to go.

They explain the first paper requiring me to write down a reason for opting out is for "data collection" and the one requiring a signature is a consent for the private search [I didn't ask for]. They are stapled together. This freaked me out, but I'm already on weird lists, so🤷‍♀️

They ask again why I'm opting out, I mention that I work with human rights organizations and am interested in changing security procedures around the world, and it seems like not many people opt out anymore, huh? *polite smile* She says by 2020 there will be no opt out. Silence.

"I don't request a private screening," I volunteer. "We only do private screenings now. Procedure." We walk a good 50m to a tiny room, they close & lock the door and I'm shown some paperwork. (This has NEVER happened before, and I've been opting out forever, all over the world)

Surprise! I'm randomly selected. I smile, "Ok, now I opt out?!" No one else smiles. I'm asked to wait, again, then asked to take off shoes and point out my bags. Standard. They move my bags (with my passport) behind the glass for "safekeeping" and I'm asked to come with them.

She said this new machine does random selection as you walk through to determine if you need a scan, so why don't I just go through and see if I even need to opt out. Seems weird since I can't confirm what actually happens when I walk through, but ok. It's the only way.

When I saw folks getting scanned, I requested to opt out. They asked why, I said data privacy. I was asked to sit & wait. A manager was called. She asked why. Again, I said data privacy. "It doesn't store data," she says. "It's my right, yes?" She is not happy.

I came in through the dedicated Virgin upper class entrance, which has its own checkin, security and a different scanner. (Client paid expenses, don't hate :P) This is relevant because even though this experience sucked, I was treated better than anybody else would be.

Opting out of the body scanner at Heathrow used to take 5 minutes. Today it was a 30 minute procedure including documenting a written reason for exercising my right of refusal and signing a document, a thread:

@rhhackett However carved up
or pared down we get
we keep on making
the best of it as though
it doesn’t matter that
our acre’s down to
a square foot. As
though our garden
could be one bean
and we’d rejoice if
it flourishes, as

@TaeRoyle @WeldPond Legal agreements to allow telephone line fax docs in the 1970s were based on naive (nonexistent) security assumptions; that they persist today has more to do with how emphatic counsel is about following precedent in case of a court dispute than how faxes or email work today.

@leah_cb I’m looking to curate a list of projects that, 10 years from now, will still exist and will be making the world a better place for humans at a rate higher than those projects with purely capital-accrual goals, and that have (or support adoption of) P2P/Web3/DLT architecture. :)

@Jomari_P @mikejschmitz “Social good” (to me) *especially* implies working with marginalized or at-risk populations who need design teams who thought ahead about these things (and don’t necessarily cave at first sign of bad use). Apps that only function when everyone follows the rules can be harmful.

@Jomari_P @mikejschmitz If the goal of a project is to become “decentralized” & it’s a public system, that *should* mean loss of control over later-stage outcomes. Every app that lets you freecycle bikes can be creatively repurposed to facilitate sex work or make illegal trades (not the same thing).

@brucefenton Yeah yeah yeah I’m aware 😉 but I’m hoping to discover a handful of high quality projects I don’t already know about. For example, even teams helping non-profits accept BTC or build highly usable wallets/onboarding tools in foreign languages might be a good fit.

Thank you so much for the responses thus far, keep ‘em coming!
To clarify: 
- Doesn’t matter public/private chain as long as the design choice makes sense
- Would love to hear more from non-US teams solving local problems 
- This is for a real thing not my random curiosity :)
@AFDudley0 Shhhhhhhhh
@cyber_hokie Still qualifies! I think “social good” is much more likely to be an emergent property of a system than a stated design goal. :)

@mikejschmitz I tend to gauge “blockchain for social good” projects by their answer to “what would you do if you found out your app/network is being used to coordinate human trafficking or fund terrorism?” In most cases, the answer means a non-blockchain/token architecture would have sufficed.

@mikejschmitz It’s a term that’s used to make people feel good, but too often equates to technical colonialism or is long-term incompatible with a for-profit entity. New technology is rarely a magic answer to a longstanding human problem.
@ZoeJDolan Yeah yeah yeah, it's already on the list. I need to crowdsource things that might not be on my radar. ;)

Anyway, hope this is a fun read for a holiday. I appreciate the "only talk about the work" women-in-tech mantra, but that doesn't obviate the mental space allocated to making a "professional appearance" seem effortless. It's not. https://t.co/lnW6rB6H1G

This Instagram world makes women feel like they should be good at all things in all contexts. Figuring out how to fit in with minimal effort is a small act of rebellion. In other ways it's being tacit in a system of hurtful economic & social class cues. Passing is privilege.

So when I was on an automate-my-life kick ("Having It All" is a lot of paid services that approximate the emotional labor of a stay-at-home-spouse, thx Roomba + Amazon Fresh) I decided to automate performative femininity, too. AND IT WORKS. People think I know what I'm doing.

<fin>

We take for granted that much of the Internet as we know it was developed here at home, and the immense benefits accrued to us because of it. Let’s discuss how to repeat the successes of the early Internet era while learning from the things we can do better this time around.

The anonymous, censorship resistant features of open blockchain currencies may turn out to be a helpful reference when beginning to discuss a digital U.S. Dollar equivalent that is as well regarded around the world as the physical dollar is today.

Ensuring one-person-one-vote while keeping ballots private is an complex computer science and human coordination problem. U.S. elections, where even traditional electronic voting machines are continually demonstrated to be vulnerable to being hacked, don’t belong on a blockchain

Along with understanding who controls access to the network and who can modify the rules of the system, identifying if “emergency escape hatches” exist and who controls them might be helpful in sorting tokens into asset classes once a sensible taxonomy has been established.

We may be building next-generation, systemically important infrastructure for the American economy & should think about how to balance the potential value with need for consumer protections and national security, and how to respect human and Constitutionally-protected rights

My concern isn't the race to mass cryptoasset adoption or asset class taxonomy. As evidenced by DMCA, Net Neutrality, FOSTA/SESTA & discussions of state-mandated cryptographic backdoors, the government will have a huge impact on how we will all be able to use this "new internet"

So far, money seems to be the killer app for blockchain, much as email was for the early Internet. P2P payments will likely grow & persist as a ubiquitous part of our personal and professional daily processes.

FWIW, livestreams are a great way to democratize access, which Ethereal & Consensus both do well. I will be speaking at both, and while I’m not getting paid for either, I get a ton of value out of being there in person and they’re local for me. So, see you there! :)

@ZoeJDolan This same dynamic plays out across every industry I can think of with a robust conference circuit, and is why @SecurityBSides etc. eventually arise. Conferences are expensive, but the profitability is also highly variable depending on sponsors etc.

Since I went indie I’m -$1000 across 4 events, & I hustled to break even. I’ve declined events that would cost me $$$, thrown by orgs who would use me to generate content for their platform but can’t be bothered to pay me. If you’re not getting paid, you are the product.

The irony of high-priced conferences is they’re the ones least likely to be paying speakers within the community, who care the most & need the platform to share new work. Corporate expense accounts subsidize people who rarely say anything novel, “celeb keynotes” extract high fees

@wifflwaffl Completely agree that tech confs who magically forget to put women on anything but panels about diversity are Doing It Wrong, but often it’s just “bonus” work. E.g. I was at SXSW to talk about my work, so I did the Ethereal inclusivity event because I was already there.

But it is important to understand & respect that we all go through cycles of benefiting from others’ advocacy, paying it forward, and burning out or just getting “selfishly engrossed” in our own work. It’s ok!
